title: The worst city design fails
text:
Email a friend 
SOMETIMES, it seems like city planners must have it in for us. 
There are some bustling cities that are very hard to explore due to their design, whether it be a lack of pedestrian access or streets that make no sense when you try to navigate them. 
From our very own Sydney to Jakarta and South Korea, here are some cities that are quite challenging to explore. 
1. DUBAI, UAE 
For a place that has spared no expense in the battle to be the biggest and best at everything — from its dazzling skyscrapers to its gigantic shopping centres and fleet of luxury police supercars — there’s one major oversight. 
It’s incredibly difficult to walk around outside of its attractions and buildings due to a lack of pedestrian walkways. And, with its roads full of cars going at top speeds, you can’t just nick across the street wherever you like. 
Just want to stroll over from the shopping centre back to your hotel? Yeah right. There’s a reason people drive everywhere. Get ready to hop in a car in Dubai. Picture: Fabio Achilli 
2. DHAKA, BANGLADESH 
This statistic gives an indication of what it’s like getting around here; in Dhaka, there are 650 major intersections but just 60 traffic lights to deal with millions of vehicles. And many of those don’t work. 
That’s a sign of the broader problems facing this city that has boomed from a population of 1.2 million in 1970 to more than 14 million now. 
As the Bangladesh Financial Express reports: “Decades of unplanned urbanisation has given birth to unbearable traffic congestions, environmental pollution, waterlogging during rains and many such problems.” 
Because it’s so hard to get in and out of Dhaka, many people are forced to live in poor conditions on the outskirts of the city, Thrillist reports. Dhaka is one of the most overpopulated cities in the world. 
3. JAKARTA, INDONESIA 
The situation in the Indonesian capital is so bad that it was this year named the place with the worst traffic in the world. 
Drivers spend an average of 400 hours each year getting to and from work, according to Institute of Transportation and Development Policy (ITDP) research, the Jakarta Post reports. 
And with the number of car owners climbing, amid a lacking public transport system and a population of nearly 10 million, something needs to be done urgently. Jakarta’s congestion. Picture: VasenkaPhotography 
4. BOSTON, US 
Boston’s layout is so confusing that scientists have even weighed in on it. 
The historical city’s winding, crooked streets, which were formerly paths for cows, were built to no particular planned pattern. But scientist and data visualiser Seth Kadish believes the confusing layout has worsened due to the lack of north, south, east and west orientation on the streets, Boston.com reports. 
“If you’re like me, and you use the sun to navigate, you probably appreciate cities with gridded street plans that are oriented in the cardinal directions,” Mr Kadish wrote on his blog the Visual Statistix . 
“If you know that your destination is due west, even if you hit a dead end or two, you’ll be able to get there. I was always amazed by the crazy Boston streets.” Mind-boggling Boston. Picture: Art N. 
5. LAGOS, NIGERIA 
With hidden traffic signs, large potholes in the roads and many drivers rumoured to have never gone to driving school, it’s a challenge to get around Lagos. 
The article 25 Rules of Engagement: Lagos Driving lesson 101 by local website Vanguard has some tongue-in-cheek pointers for the uninitiated including: “When in doubt, accelerate”, “there is no such thing as ‘one-way’ in Lagos” and “never, ever, stop for a pedestrian unless he flings himself under the wheels of your car”. Lagos, Nigeria. Picture: Nick M 
6. SYDNEY 
The map below says it all. Good luck with the navigating, everybody! Sydney, what were you thinking? Now that’s more like it, Melbourne. Stunning Eagle's-Eye View of Dubai 1:51
